Research 
The narrow-leaved lavantula, the common lavender and the lavantula the stoichas, known as 
myrrh-bearing and wild lavender, belong to the family of Lips and to the category of aroma=c 
plants.  
They are perennial bushy plants, have leaves elongated, slightly fluffy rather fleshy and silvery 
color. Their characteris=c difference is their flowering, where in the first the flowers are lip-
shaped, violet and are located in sparse, extreme inflorescence, while in the wild they are violet 
and are located in extreme, dense ears. They bloom in spring, the first in gardens, and the 
second in dry lands, stony soils and rivers in the semi-mountainous areas of our island.  
The lavantula stoichas is a na=ve plant of the Mediterranean countries and is men=oned by Pliny 
and Dioscorides, ornamental lavender is a hybrid of wild. Today there are several ornamental 
varie=es, cul=vated for their essen=al oil, although the highest quality oil is that given by the

There are several interes=ng records about lavender and its use.  
Lavender was one of the first plants used by man since an=quity for ornamental purposes. Its 
name comes from the La=n Lavare which means to wash because they threw lavender flowers in 
their bathrooms to aroma=ze them. A habit established by the Romans.  
Lavender bags had their place in chests and cupboards, to scent clothes and drive away the 
moth. Even on the linings of clothes they sewed lavender for these purposes.  
With its oil they smeared the legs of their beds to get rid of bed bugs. With the same oil they 
smeared the heads of children to rid them of lice. It was also used to treat lavomas.  
Hunters knew they could save themselves and their dogs from viper bites if they hunted in a 
place where lavender grew. They melted its leaves and deposited them on

ey could save themselves and their dogs from viper bites if they hunted in a 
place where lavender grew. They melted its leaves and deposited them on wounds.  
The latest research has proven that lavender essen=al oil is an ac=ve an=sep=c for diphtheria 
bacillus and typhus, for streptococci and pneumococci and an ac=ve an=dote for poisons.  
Lavender is connected to the history of aromatherapy. In 1920, Rene Maurice GaRefosse burned 
badly in an explosion in the chemical laboratory of his family factory that made aroma=c oils. 
The first thing he found handy to ease his pains was pure lavender oil. He no=ced that the 
treatment was quick and the healing without a sign. This prompted him to begin his research 
into the healing proper=es of fragrances. ASer eight years of experimenta=on, he published the 

first book on aromatherapy and marked the beginning of aromatherapy as a separate branch of 
therapy.

Dosage  
Dosage: 1 tablespoon in half a glass of water, morning, noon and evening.

Note: 
The taste comes from oils in the cell walls of plants. CuYng or grinding breaks cell walls and

Dried herbs can be effec=vely stored up to a year in a cool, dry, dark place.
